articles.headline: U.S. Sanctions Turn Iran’s Oil Industry Into Spy vs. Spy
articles.snippet: Accused C.I.A. spies are said to have been gathering intelligence on oil sales, data that the Americans want and that Iran wants to keep secret.
articles.abstract: Accused C.I.A. spies are said to have been gathering intelligence on oil sales, data that the Americans want and that Iran wants to keep secret.
articles.lead_paragraph: They change offices every few months and store documents only in hard copy. They scan their businesses for covert listening devices and divert all office calls to their cellphones. They know they are under surveillance, and assume their electronics are hacked.

articles.headline: Help for the Economy? Despite Grumbling, Trump Has Had Plenty
articles.snippet: The Fed and Congress have given President Trump the most growth-friendly climate in decades. But the trade war may test its limits.
articles.abstract: The Fed and Congress have given President Trump the most growth-friendly climate in decades. But the trade war may test its limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump has complained that the Federal Reserve has been hurting the economy, first by raising interest rates and then by not lowering them fast enough. “No help from Fed!” he said on Twitter last week, in what has become a typical broadside.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley, Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Uber Posts $5.2 Billion Loss and Slowest Ever Growth Rate
articles.snippet: The double whammy immediately renewed questions about the prospects of the world’s biggest ride-hailing company.
articles.abstract: The double whammy immediately renewed questions about the prospects of the world’s biggest ride-hailing company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber set two dubious quarterly records on Thursday as it reported its results: its largest-ever loss, exceeding $5 billion, and its slowest-ever revenue growth.

articles.headline: The Next Front in the Fight Over Gun Control? Virginia
articles.snippet: The state’s elections in November will test the potency of gun rights as a voting issue. Democrats are looking to take power and enact gun control legislation next year.
articles.abstract: The state’s elections in November will test the potency of gun rights as a voting issue. Democrats are looking to take power and enact gun control legislation next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: CENTREVILLE, Va. — At door after door, house after house, Dan Helmer, a Democrat running for the Virginia House of Delegates, found voters of both parties telling him one thing as he canvassed for support Tuesday night: Do something about the mass shootings.

articles.headline: Trump Weighs New Stance on Guns as Pressure Mounts After Shootings
articles.snippet: The president is consulting allies about supporting expanded background checks. Mitch McConnell said the idea would be “front and center” when the Senate reconvenes.
articles.abstract: The president is consulting allies about supporting expanded background checks. Mitch McConnell said the idea would be “front and center” when the Senate reconvenes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the wake of two mass shootings, the divisive politics of gun control appeared to be in flux on Thursday as President Trump explored whether to back expanded background checks on gun purchasers and Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader, signaled that he would at least be open to considering the idea.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: They Paid $42 for a SoulCycle Ride, Not for Trump
articles.snippet: A look at what happens when politics enters every spandex-clad corner of life, especially in the Hamptons.
articles.abstract: A look at what happens when politics enters every spandex-clad corner of life, especially in the Hamptons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATER MILL, N.Y. — Dressed in workout clothes, Lulu Hall hovered by the front door of the SoulCycle studio while fighting back tears.

articles.headline: Trump’s Opponents Want to Name His Big Donors. His Supporters Say It’s Harassment.
articles.snippet: Calling out campaign donors isn’t a new political tactic, but the question of how much should be publicly disclosed about them has been an issue repeatedly raised by Republicans in recent years.
articles.abstract: Calling out campaign donors isn’t a new political tactic, but the question of how much should be publicly disclosed about them has been an issue repeatedly raised by Republicans in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For many businesses, a sudden deluge of phone calls might signal an influx of new customers. But most of the 25 calls Justin Herricks received before noon on Thursday were from people who wanted to tell him he was a white supremacist for donating money to President Trump.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Annie Karni

articles.headline: How Many Hogs Can Be Slaughtered Per Hour? Pork Industry Wants More
articles.snippet: A proposed federal rule would essentially do away with speed limits at pork processing plants. Some watchdog groups worry it will threaten worker and consumer safety.
articles.abstract: A proposed federal rule would essentially do away with speed limits at pork processing plants. Some watchdog groups worry it will threaten worker and consumer safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government is poised this month to adopt a rule that would essentially turn the largest pork processing lines in the United States into the autobahn: no speed limit.

articles.headline: What Worries Iceland? A World Without Ice. It Is Preparing.
articles.snippet: As rising temperatures drastically reshape Iceland’s landscape, businesses and the government are spending millions for survival and profit.
articles.abstract: As rising temperatures drastically reshape Iceland’s landscape, businesses and the government are spending millions for survival and profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: HÖFN, Iceland — From the offices of the fishing operation founded by his family two generations ago, Adalsteinn Ingólfsson has watched the massive Vatnajökull glacier shrink year after year. Rising temperatures have already winnowed the types of fish he can catch. But the wilting ice mass, Iceland’s largest, is a strange new challenge to business.

articles.headline: More Private Colleges Are Cutting Tuition, but Don’t Expect to Pay Less
articles.snippet: Few students actually paid the published cost. Colleges worried that they would be bypassed if families looked just at the sticker price.
articles.abstract: Few students actually paid the published cost. Colleges worried that they would be bypassed if families looked just at the sticker price.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sunshine Anderson was at Mills College’s annual welcoming ceremony in 2017 when the liberal arts college revealed its big news: It was slashing its tuition by more than a third.

articles.headline: This High-Tech Solution to Disaster Response May Be Too Good to Be True
articles.snippet: Major cities are turning to a Silicon Valley start-up to help save lives in an emergency. But some fear its promise has been dangerously exaggerated.
articles.abstract: Major cities are turning to a Silicon Valley start-up to help save lives in an emergency. But some fear its promise has been dangerously exaggerated.

articles.headline: Italy’s Biggest Economic Problem? It’s Still Italy
articles.snippet: Political chaos and confrontation with the European Union over spending rules have reinforced what a finance professor calls the country’s “serial stagnation.”
articles.abstract: Political chaos and confrontation with the European Union over spending rules have reinforced what a finance professor calls the country’s “serial stagnation.”
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Whatever hopes there were that a radically unconventional government might jolt Italy out of its economic torpor have mostly given way to bitter resignation that, in this country, nothing ever seems to change.

articles.headline: Past Flip-Flops Cloud Trump’s Position on Background Checks
articles.snippet: Whether the president’s support is real or another momentary reversal will determine if Congress passes the first new federal gun control measures in years.
articles.abstract: Whether the president’s support is real or another momentary reversal will determine if Congress passes the first new federal gun control measures in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2013, Donald J. Trump said he supported background checks for gun purchases to “weed out the sickos.” Two years later, as he prepared to run for president, he flip-flopped, telling Ammoland magazine that he opposed expanded checks because they don’t work.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
